docTitle.titlePart: Notes on a Journey via Paris to London, Leeds, Low Moor, Sheffield, and Back in the Summer of 1845.

titlePage.byline: By Johann Conrad Fischer, Lieutenant Colonel of the Artillery.
titlePage.docImprint: Schaffhausen. Printed by J. J. Biegler’schen Buchdruckerei. 1846.

div.head: Preface
div.p: When I first visited England 52 years ago, and there, having found employ with a mechanic in London, Mr. Rhé of Shoe Lane, Fleet Street, through which I had occasion to compare the extent to which this branch of industry had advanced and been perfected as opposed to that on the Continent, I must confess that my verdict was wholly in favour of England, and that scarcely any object of industry in this or that field need fear rivalry from abroad, a circumstance to which the early introduction of the patent system with its capacity to offer both inducements and protections might well have contributed, ensuring that the wares produced, almost without exception, combine a high degree of perfection with both solidity and utility.

Yet to the best of my knowledge, there was nothing especially new to be seen there – with the exception of steam engines, which on the Continent were all but unknown at the time – since the same things might be found elsewhere, only not as good.

When, twenty years later, I visited this curious island again the moment the Continental Blockade was lifted, I found great new phenomena in the aforementioned fields. The spinning mills, iron foundries, potteries, among which Wedgwood seemed the primus inter pares or rather the princeps, the steel and file factories, Birmingham and Sheffield plate, the spun cotton and mechanical looms of Manchester and the textile mills of Leeds had taken on a character of greatness and perfection of which, without seeing them for oneself, one can have no concept.

Twelve or thirteen years later, when inclination and interest drove me to this country once again, the scale of everything, most notably the extent of London, had grown even more, so that a member of parliament, when the matter was debated in September of that same year, had occasion
to say: “this year had seen the building of 26,000 new houses by the end of last week, though how many more will be finished by next Saturday I cannot say.”

The already widespread deployment of steamships, the introduction of gas lighting, Perkins’s steam gun and the construction of the gigantic tunnel that seemed impossible but was made possible by Brunel, alongside all manner of other most interesting things, my brief notes on which are contained in the diariesGemeint sind die Tagebücher von 1825 und von 1825–1827. I kept of my travels in those years, imprinted themselves on my mind as a composition, which through vivid recollection of the same makes for a most alluring tableau. —As already mentioned, I committed my feeble and incomplete outlines of these things to my earlier diaries, the keeping of which, through long habituation, has become a compulsion, and which readers have received kindly and, disregarding their shortcomings, judged with circumspection, perhaps precisely because I did not presume to write deliberately for others. The few pages that follow, however, in which is contained the result of last year’s very brief journey, are too paltry in content for others to be alerted to the same. They shall not, therefore,
be entrusted to the book trade, and are printed here, after the passage of almost a whole year, only because it did not seem worth my while to make them over to a publisher. It is for the sake of my family and friends, therefore, who wondered at my not having seen anything worthy of note or at my having deemed what I did see unworthy of mention, that this small volume takes its place alongside its predecessors. May they, or indeed anyone else who chances to lay hands on it, receive it as I wish, namely as a straightforward account, addressed to my own nearest and dearest, of a journey undertaken to foreign lands, and for me but one scene more in the aforementioned tableau.
Schaffhausen, the 21st June 1846.
Johann Conrad Fischer, Lieutenant Colonel.Das Tagebuch wurde 1846 bei der J. J. Ziegler’schen Buchdruckerei in Schaffhausen gedruckt.

div.head: Schaffhausen–Basel, 14. Juli 1845
div.p:
On 14th July I set off for Basel by express coach, and in Jestetten was joined by an English family, a gentleman, two ladies and a young boy, as travelling companions. They seemed pleased to have encountered one with whom they might converse in their native tongue, the occasion for which was Mr. Watson’s taking out an English map of Europe’s railways and steamship routes. After we had talked about sundry related matters, his wife, remarking on the fact that I evidently understood English, presented me with a printed pamphlet and invited me to read the same. It was a fragment of a tract published by the Tract Society in London and contained two tales of conversion (the 867th and 868th, according to the tract), one of them entitled “The Railway Passenger” and the other the “Father’s Prayer”. Out of respect for her good intentions, and for the family as people who took such matters very seriously, it seemed to me, I read both tales in their entirety, despite finding them too bland and moralistic, all the more so since they bore the stamp of well-meaning fiction rather than that of true stories. After reading them, I made to return them
but was obliged to keep them. The event reminded me of an earlier one, when one Madame Consentius of Königsberg, a great admirer of [Barbara] von Krüdener, had visited me, and on taking her leave of me had given me two such tracts, which common folk in those days believed to possess a particular smell that if inhaled would make one an adherent of that then so famous lady. Soon afterwards, Mr. Watson slipped his silver-bound New Testament out of its case and read aloud a chapter from Saint John’s Gospel, after which the conversation once again turned to more general matters.

In Lauchringen we were joined, much to my delight, by Pastor Merian of Oberhallau, to whom, since I knew that he had likewise been in England and understood English, I was able to give the aforementioned stories as reading material.

At Berg near Lauffenburg we were waylaid by a mendicant apprentice, who climbed in beside us, as did, soon afterwards, a farmer’s girl from the Black Forest wishing to avail herself of the baths in Säckingen, who was likewise given such a tract. She held onto it for some time, albeit upside-down, and would have politely returned it had not the Englishwoman exhorted her: “Keep it, keep it!” which I then translated for her, telling her that she should keep it.

Giving serious thought to what had just transpired, I wondered to myself,
as I have done repeatedly ever since, whether such endeavours, as commendable and sincerely meant as they undoubtedly are, are not bound by any propriety of time, place and circumstance? But never once have I been able to answer that question and instead attach great value to the very profound message of the apostle: “But thou, when thou prayest, enter into thy closet, and when thou hast shut the door, pray to thy Father which is in secret.”Matthäus 6,6.
On arriving in Basel that evening, my dear old friend Wibert was already at the post office to welcome me and to accommodate me under his hospitable roof.
How sorry I was that he could not be my travelling companion in England as he had been fifty years ago!

div.head: Geschäftsgänge in Basel, 15. Juli 1845
div.p: The greater part of the day was taken up with various visits and writing two letters home.

I went first to Mr. Wölflin, who had recently returned from Mexico and was just then unpacking 5 cases of natural objects and artefacts from the land of the ancient IncasFischer verwechselt die Inkas mit den Azteken.. I found them all fascinating, though most of all the Chinese objects that he had chanced to acquire, primarily a charming little pocket book, whose tortoiseshell binding was covered with characters arranged one below the other in columns, as is sometimes the case with Egyptian hieroglyphs. Its inside pages, twelve in number (they seem to have a dodecimal system, too), depicted the costumes and other attributes of the various classes of this curious people,
the faces of the women being painted onto tiny, convex slivers of ivory the size of a little fingernail, whereas the rest was all flat.

Of the four large tableaux of a sugar boiler with its own ox gin alongside it, a stove-builder’s shop, a landscape and a Chinese juggler with an entourage of monkeys and dogs, it was the latter that interested me most, having never before seen anything like it in Europe. I once saw a comedy with dogs and monkeys in Salzburg that certainly took things quite far, though for all that they were clad like the ladies and gentlemen that they supposedly represented, the faces peeping out from under the hats and bonnets were still those of dogs and monkeys. The Chinese, however, took the deception a stage further in that all had masks depending on the role they had to play, and as if that were not enough, there was a dog pulling a little cart bearing a basket full of masks, on which sat a monkey-coachman vigorously brandishing his whip.

After a visit to my friend’s family, I had two meetings with Mr. E. P., which for the most part had to do with the Schweizer-Eisenbahnen, specifically the line from Waldshut to Konstanz via Schaffhausen. He raised what seemed to be some important objections to a very well written memorandum by a highly skilled and experienced member of our trade,
namely the want of passengers on the line via Ulm to Augsburg and further east, which concern I felt bound to allay by noting that things would look very different once the line from Augsburg to Lindau was finished. As to the money for the aforementioned line, he acknowledged that while he himself, like many other Basel establishments, had perhaps been able to provide an impetus, nothing positive had as yet been discussed, it having been observed that since Baden did not wish to build the line itself, or so it had been heard, the necessary concessions on that side would first have to be secured, and that the very large sums required in such a case might well be raised in Vienna.

There was just enough time for me to tell him of my invention of bar iron, indeed the melting and casting of all wrought iron so as to retain its softness and malleability, and showed him some pieces that he took with him as specimens. Once he had seen these and tested them with a file and hammer, he cried out: “The French should have that!”, whereupon I remarked that I first wanted to hear what the English had to say.

Returning home past Basel’s many fine and sturdy public buildings and private homes,
all of them so clean and impeccably well kept both inside and out, I could not help but think that it was this same cleanliness, this same love of order – the daughters of quiet, steady industry that historically have long been at home in Basel – which in their wake have brought not some fly-by-night or will-o-the-wisp, but wealth built on solid ground and thriving as if of its own accord. A house in good order is one that is entered gladly. In this respect England, Holland, Germany and Switzerland appear in a much more favourable light than does their neighbour, which once believed itself to be the No. 1 of all the nations of this earth.

div.head: Basel–Paris, 16. bis 18. Juli 1845
div.p: My friend accompanied me as far as the post office, where I departed at 7 o’clock in the morning on the post coach from Basel to Paris, for an inside seat on which, the cabriolet being already occupied, I had to pay 56 francs. The post coach belonging to the Bureau des Diligences Royales was much finer and better furnished than it used to be. — Customs in St. Louis were not very scrupulous, and since the product specimens that I declared of 1 kilogram in weight are so valuable to me, I gladly paid the 1 franc and 46 centimes levied.

In Mulhouse I chanced to have the pleasure of lunching with three esteemed young compatriots, whose industriousness and love of business in the one or the other métier might serve others as an example to follow, and conversed with them
on sundry matters relating to industrially made objects. To judge by past experience, however, I would henceforth have to abandon all hopes of pleasure. —And indeed, it was worse than I had anticipated; for quite apart from the fact that our company consisted of a German scholar who either slept or smoked, a young French army officer, and the wife of a factory worker from Mulhouse, who as a Parisienne had been bored to death there and had left her husband to return to what she considered to be heaven on earth, we never once stopped long enough to eat anything during the 23 hours to elapse between Mulhouse and Langres (which I had not expected given previous journeys). It being bourse day in Mulhouse, we had sat down to lunch at twelve o’clock sharp and set off again at 1, and by the time we sat down to breakfast in Langres it was already 11 o’clock the next morning, the 17th JuneGemeint ist der 17. Juli.. I had no opportunity to make any important observations on that long stretch. Whereas the land was better cultivated than when I last journeyed through it in 1814, when one saw only women at the plough, the coupes régulières undertaken by Napoleon and his young cadre for the honour of the nation, or more likely his own glory, had in the meantime ceased. But the peasants’ dwellings in Champagne, even as far as Troyes, where we arrived around midnight
and were able to drink a cup of coffee, were just as wretched as ever, especially when one compares their timbering, roofing, cramped conditions, workmanship, disposition and general filth to those of Swiss farmhouses.
We breakfasted à la fourchette in a small town just beyond Nangis and arrived in Paris at 4 o’clock in the afternoon of the 18th.

Following one of the calling cards with which one is so generously regaled on alighting from the diligence, I sought lodgings at the Hôtel du Havre on the rue des vieux Augustins. I cannot complain, since after my 50-hour journey and a light supper I was happy just to see a bed again, though I would not recommend this inn to anyone else.

div.head: Pariser Mode, Münzanstalt und Weiterreise, 19. Juli 1845
div.p:
On the journey from Mulhouse to Paris (since the diligence from Basel returns that same day), I discovered above the filêts inside the carriage a printed pamphlet, which I leafed through out of sheer boredom. It was titled la Diligence and seems to have been placed there deliberately, since it contained a whole host of advertisements for shops in Paris, contained within which were some blandly written stories, spiked with far-fetched words that do not belong to common parlance, which in spirit and style are very similar to those used in today’s fashion magazines. Among the advertisements was one which, to stand out from the others, had white letters on a black ground
and began with the rallying cry “Mort aux chapeaux de soie!” [Death to silk hats!], followed by a paean to the castor hats of the very best quality that Mr. Biget (to be found at rue Rivoli no. 56) was selling for 17 francs a piece. Needing such a hat, I set off thence and consequently had to walk all the way back to the prefecture, before venturing even further afield to the banker Mr. Dassier, in whose counting house I met a young man from Schaffhausen (Rauschenbach), who deservedly enjoys great confidence there. After that it was off to Mr. Bréant's mint, which does such great work in platinum, and there, with Mr. Bréant himself guiding me through that labyrinthine building, to Mr. Barre to take provisional orders for steel for coin punches of a quality that might rival that used for the excellent coins made by Munich’s award-winning mint. These two gentlemen viewed my specimens of cast soft bar iron (the lockplate and cock of a percussion flintlock) with interest, and Mr. Bréant took the opportunity to tell me, much to my surprise, that they still had no really good crucibles in France and still preferred the Passau model.

After the mint, and shortly before departing on the diligence to Calais, I had to return to the prefecture, though only after calling at the Swiss delegation, where
a sum of 2 francs was demanded for the appendage of a stamp to my passport, presumably for the sake of the people of that nation, since not a single penny was asked of me anywhere else. Meanwhile, my errantry, as I can with some justification call it, afforded me something pleasant and unexpected in the form of the obelisk of Luxor, that fine monolith, a drawing of which I once possessed, albeit without knowing the interpretation of the hieroglyphs according to the key provided by Champollion.

Three thoughts occurred to me on viewing this curious object: either Egypt in those days had had a large population of idlers that might be put to work on this seemingly futile undertaking, which given Egypt’s fertility and the small amount of effort required to work the land there is entirely plausible, or the ambitions of its rulers surpassed all moderation in the same proportion as the pyramids do ordinary buildings, to prove which one might cite Herodotus, or it had been agreed, which would be the most praiseworthy of these three theories, that there should be an enduring monument to the history, the laws and the mores of those times. —

When this gift of Ali Pascha to the King of FranceDie Schenkung fällt in die Herrschaft von Karl X. Der Transport und das Aufstellen des Obelisken in Paris geschah unter Louis-Philippe I., which would be further embellished by its proximity to two extremely copious fountains (that the French have taste cannot be denied),
was first erected, the gazettes mocked the idea of mounting a pointed column on a pedestal. Quite apart from the fact that the newspapers are not the word of god, any impartial observer is bound to concede that the idea was in fact a good one. The throne of a king is likewise elevated above its surroundings, and this king, too, undoubtedly deserved a lofty position under all those stones.

At half past two, feeling amply recompensed for all the hardships of the day by my reception at the mint, I paid 33 francs for a stage-coach to Calais and left Paris. As the capital’s new wall with its detached bastions (which only future times may judge) receded into the distance, I was glad to be entering the pretty region of Normandy, France’s very own Thurgau.

Shortly after midnight, the right-hand horse of the diligence stumbled and became so ensnared in its traces that we lost almost a whole hour, which in turn robbed us passengers of a whole day, since the steamships from Boulogne sur mer and Calais depart at a fixed hour every day.

div.head: Boulogne–Calais, 20. Juli 1845
div.p:
Arrived in Boulogne at 10 o’clock in the morning. One travels so uncommonly fast compared to times past, and that despite all the passengers and goods. The French have learned this from the English,
though they have yet to adopt their horses and fine, sturdy bridles. The 72-hour journey from Paris is now accomplished in just 18 hours. The swindling that goes on at the inns en route is extraordinary. No one takes anything without first asking what it costs, and the insistence of the persons employed to recommend lodgings in Boulogne is remarkable. —The harassment began 4 hours outside Boulogne at the foot of a steep hill where the horses had to slow down to a walking pace and some women were waiting to thrust their addresses into every passing coach; but just an hour nearer to Boulogne and we were again waylaid by three urchins on ponies, each of whom held a long hazel switch with calling cards clamped into its split end, so that by trotting briskly along beside the coach, they were able to poke these inside to us passengers. —The diligence did not linger long in Boulogne and I arrived in Calais at 2 o’clock in the afternoon. The inn where I used to stay, the Hotel de St. Louis, had gone under; but I had a lucky star in the guise of an officer of the gendarmerie, who on my approaching him for directions guided me to an English establishment, (Commercial Inn, Mr. Warren), where I fancied myself already in England, the family having brought with them all the customs of their home country, characteristic among which was their practice of having one person in the dining room reverentially read aloud from the Bible (it was a Sunday) while his neighbour
downed copious amounts of rum, albeit very quietly, as is also customary in England.

div.head: Querung des Ärmelkanals und Herr Hamers Reisetipps, 21. Juli 1845
div.p:
I slept for ten hours, which is surely pardonable in one who has been travelling for 8 days and who between Basel and Calais only once saw a bed (in Paris, to be precise). Well might I afford myself that pleasure, for our Royal Mail Steamship, having a draught of just 7 feet, could not put to sea until high tide, which arrived late at around 10 o’clock in the morning. The company on the steamer, which despite its small size was furnished with a 65 horsepower engine that in defiance of wind and waves drove the wheels at a rate of 29 revolutions per minute, was not very numerous, as almost all travellers who make the journey from France to England take the route from Boulogne sur mer to Folkstone, a little port on the English coast, where they meet a branch line of the Dover-London railway. Calais, astonishingly, has suffered because of this, since anyone who wants to be at sea for just a few hours can now make the crossing via Boulogne and complete the passage in just 26¼ hours, whereas anyone who travels from London to Dieppe via Brighton, a journey entailing 74 miles at sea, and from there continues by train to Paris will reach the same in the incredibly short time of just 16¼ hours, having covered 244 English miles altogether. The total costs of this journey over land and sea from Paris to London or vice
versa, including all the railway and omnibus fares and lodgings – though not what is consumed en route, which of course one can limit as one wishes – are in the order of 60 fr. or 30 fl. at most, at least as long as one does not take a seat in the coupé of the diligence or in a first-class carriage on the railway but instead contents oneself with an inside seat and a second-class carriage. Here I am bound to make a remark that the parents of sons, who whether by inclination or for professional reasons or other circumstances venture forth into the world, would do well to take to heart, should they ever set eyes on it: Since the intercourse among nations has multiplied so greatly of late and been so greatly facilitated by the advent of steamships and railways, learning French and English in addition to one’s mother tongue (I am addressing German-speakers here), and prior to that some Latin, be it ever so little, since that language is the foundation and mother of the other two, as it were, has become a matter of the utmost urgency. Yet too many of us are loath to acknowledge this, or so it seems to me, and though the benefits to be derived from it need no further articulation here, I shall nevertheless provide a few examples of my own. There were, as I said, but a few passengers on the steamship, and all of them English. Although I conversed with most of those on board in turn, one of them in particular
took a special shine to me precisely because I spoke English so fluently, or so he told me, so that not only did he tell me everything that I might possibly want to know about what was to be done at customs and the “Aliens Office” in Dover and explain to me how to procure a seat on the train to London, an 88-mile journey that can now be accomplished in 3 hours, but he also gave me a permit to see the Chinese Collection at Hyde-Park Corner, which cannot be viewed for money, despite containing the finest and most intriguing artefacts from that country, that has now been returned to the world, as it were.Wohl eine Anspielung auf das Ende des Ersten Opiumkriegs und der daraus resultierenden Öffnung Chinas für den Welthandel. Mr. Hamer (not Hammer, which is also a word in English) also told me that on arriving at the station in London, I should hand over my luggage to a porter and have him take it – a service for which I would not have to pay a penny – to a cab, which for just one shilling would take me to whichever part of London I wished. —I pondered the word “cab” for some time, since I did not recall ever having heard it before; after asking for an explanation, however, it turned out that the English, being such assiduous time-keepers, have substituted this word for the word “cabriolet”, which after all is three syllables longer.

My desire to become seasick, since I always feel better thereafter,
was not fulfilled, despite my having scooped up a cup of green seawater and downed it all at once shortly after departing Calais, a method which has never before failed me. —When inspecting the inner fittings of the ship I came across an object, which on grounds of its simplicity and the effectiveness of its intended purpose, which was to bring diffuse light to the dark rooms below decks by means of just a small opening in the overhead, interested me greatly. Never before had I encountered an optical, or rather dioptical, tool being used in such a way. As the ship, owing to its low draught and to prevent seepage on a stormy sea, had very few high and low portholes (windows) mounted on its sides, each of the completely dark rooms below had a single glass prism inserted into a hole in the middle of the overhead, though always somewhat sunken into the deck so as to prevent it getting trodden on by the shoes of those pacing to and fro. This prism, each triangular face of which was circa 6 inches in length and 2 inches wide, was protected by a very thin and slender copper frame or mount that was nailed onto the wood, and that despite having a squared surface area in a ratio of 12:2500 to the smallest room to be illuminated provided real daylight.
Might we all be as conscientious as they are in England about taking whatever is of practical benefit from a scientific discipline and actually putting it to use!

div.head: «Sind Sie auch in England, Herr Obrist?», 21. Juli 1845
div.p:
We landed in Dover in glorious weather at about 1 o’clock in the afternoon. Having previously been told what I had to do and where, I was astonished at the ease, the assurance and the calm with which our goods were transferred from the ship to the customs house and from there to the inn. Only the owner of the goods was admitted to the long table, of which the room contained several, on which all the cases, bags, chests etc. were laid out ready for inspection. Upon my declaration of those objects that I had in my case on which duty might be payable, I was politely told that it was not worth their while, which of course is wiser than wasting time filling 3 full sheets of paper with written descriptions all for the sake of a few kreuzers. Not even the paper in which the said items were wrapped was removed; instead they were merely lifted off the table. It was all over in less than 3 minutes, and for a fare of sixpence (eighteen kreuzer) a customs house employee took my effects to the inn. I now had to report to the aliens office; it cannot really be called a police station, as there were no people with frightful moustaches, grim faces and crooked tobacco pipes there. It rather consisted of just one uncommonly small room and in it a friendly gentleman
clad all in black, as are almost all people of quality in England. Here I had nothing to do other than to write my name on three printed certificates of arrival, one of which was handed over to me, while the other two he retained. It all took just two minutes. England, it seems, is not as afraid of foreigners as its neighbouring country. I can now stay as long as I wish, go wherever I wish, and, according to this certificate, am not subject to any conditions such as having to report to the officer in charge at the port of embarkation prior to my departure. In France, by contrast, despite being in possession of a passport issued by [the Swiss] authorities and signed by the French ambassador, I was unable to get out of the country without first having to run hither and thither, to endure all sorts of travails, and pay money for them to boot. Here, by contrast, entering and remaining in the country is facilitated in the extreme.

The officer then asked me how things stood in Switzerland? to which I replied that there was not much to boast about there. He responded to this merely by remarking that it seemed to him that through the attack on Lucerne, both sidesGemeint sind wohl die Liberal-Radikalen und die Katholisch-Konservativen. had now gone too far – which incidentally is a view that thousands upon thousands of us who have not been blinded by passion would subscribe to. While some, on reading this, would find my account of this day tedious, the reason I chose to record
it in such detail in my diary was to ensure that at least my nearest and dearest might form a vivid picture of how good it is to have some prior knowledge of the language of every country, and this one in particular. How many pleasures would I have missed, how many embarrassments would I have suffered, had I not known the whys and wherefores? —The French entertain this preconceived notion that one has to learn their language (la langue de l'Univers), yet do not thank one for it when one proves oneself capable of conversing with them in the same; the English, by contrast, while equally entitled to such grand claims, are more modest and show affection and respect for those who speak their mother-tongue, as I have experienced many times.

When I was at dinner in Dover, I suddenly heard someone behind me ask: “So you, too, are in England, Mr. Obrist?” and on turning round saw that it was Professor Schönbein of Basel. My delight on seeing him here, however, was greatly mitigated by our having but a few minutes in which to converse, I being on my way to London and he to Paris, and by the news that my esteemed friend Mr. Faraday was not at present in England. I bid him a good journey and said that should he choose to attend the forthcoming convention of the Swiss Naturalists’ Society in Geneva,
an event that I have always found stimulating and worthwhile but this year will not be able to attend, he should kindly extend my apologies to its president, Mr. de la Rive.

div.head: Von Dover nach London mit der Eisenbahn, 21. Juli 1845
div.p: The train departed Dover at 3 o’clock. On the advice of my new friend Mr. Hamer, who remained my travelling companion as far as Folkstone, I took a seat in the second class, for which the fare for the 88-mile journey was 10 shillings and 6 pence, or 6 fl. and 18 kr.

“I can already see that you care about our country and its people and ask all sorts of questions,” said he. “It is here in this class, where you will encounter a better sort of people, that you will obtain the most information, whereas I could not and would not recommend the third class, and as for the first class, not only is it populated mainly by fine ladies, but the prevailing tone there is very stiff and formal.” —Not far from Dover we came to that curious place where, harnessing those elemental forces over which we now have dominion and that through science can make our servants, a whole mountain made of limestone was cast all at once into the depths of the sea solely to make room for the genius of steam trains.Fischer meint die Sprengung von Round Down Cliff am 26. Januar 1843. Somewhat later we passed through several tunnels of quite some length, our entrance into which was invariably advertised by a loud scream on the part of the locomotive. —The extreme darkness that reigns supreme in these passages makes one concur with Schiller:

“A dark and mysterious gate opens wide.
Beyond seem the shadow realms dreaded.
But sudden a region of bliss is descried.
Where autumn and spring-time are wedded”,Zweite Strophe aus Friedrich Schillers Gedicht «Berglied», 1804. ((trans. Edgar Alfred Bowring, 1851))
– for the surrounding countryside is truly very fine and richly cultivated.

At the speed at which one now travels – on the railways, that is – everything flies by so fast that it is impossible to get a proper look at anything, still less to compose a description of it. Earlier times were better for that, as can be read in the thick volumes by Nikolai in BerlinNikolai [Gretsch] in Berlin and the account of Sophie’s Journey from Memel to Saxony. — Nonetheless, I took note of several objects that to me seemed not entirely trivial. First, there are the hop gardens that are so frequent here on England’s southern and south-eastern flank. Had I not known that there are no vineyards in England, I would have mistaken them for vines such as those that grow in our parts, for they use the same circa 6-foot-long stakes, space them the same 33 to 36 inches apart, and treat the soil in much the same way too. How much timber must be saved compared to Germany’s 20-foot-long hop poles? How much easier the procurement? And how many more plants can be grown on the same area? Being no agronomist, I shall refrain from passing judgment, though I am bound to believe that the calmly analytical and mathematically minded Englishmen
must have found a significant advantage in this manner of hop-growing. Second, there is the electro-galvanicKorrekturanweisung aus Erstdruck: «Correctur. Statt electrogalvanische, lies: electromagnetische». telegraph, whose 4 copper wires run alongside the railway from one specially erected pole to the next, and whose speedy reports leave even the fastest steam train far behind them like a lame horse; and third, there are the timber underlays for the iron rails, of which all those that I have seen in Germany and France were elongated rectangles or had a rounded underside, whereas those in England are equilateral triangles, which makes perfect sense to me; and not just because of the timber that is saved in this way, since they can be cut apart out of relatively thick planks, but also because on pondering the matter further, having at first glance not known what to make of them, I realised that as paradoxical as it seems, their resistance to the pressure from above, disregarding that from the sides, will be greater than that of the aforementioned shapes or cross-sections. At New Cross, 10 miles from London, I at last came to that important place where an atmospheric line is being laid parallel to the conventional one. This bold and audacious idea proves that no one in England is deterred by difficulties that do not carry within them
the impossibility of their removal. A large part of the tube, which depending on the needs of the moment is either open or sealed tight, has been laid (Dublin has had such a line in operation for some time now), and on my pending return from the north of England I shall doubtless have occasion to make further remarks on this great innovation. Since it is still fiercely contested, if only on account of the many interests imperilled by it, I shall confine myself for now to observing that the rails are not only thinner than those of the ordinary railway alongside it, but also thinner than those that I saw in France and Germany – unless my eyes, in which I generally have great confidence, deceive me. How much difference in weight such a ⅓ reduction in thickness and breadth actually brings per mile of line, assuming that third to be truly superfluous, I leave it to those to calculate who know, as does Nature herself, how to apply the lex parsimoniae without impairing solidity.

At last I had the pleasure of arriving in London – healthy and happy, thank God – at 6 o’clock in the evening, and half an hour later was at my lodgings at the Bull & Mouth Inn located opposite the Post Office. Thus a journey that had not been entirely free of travails, and with it today’s diary entry, ended with a letter home.

div.head: Alte und neue Bekanntschaften in London, 22. Juli 1845
div.p:
My most pressing appointment on the 22nd was at the mint, where I was to meet Mr. Brande, an outstanding
chemist, who holds the important post of “Master of the Die Office”. On being told that he was in the country, I left him a copy of the letter, which I had previously translated into English, that the assayer Mr. Haindl of Munich had been so kind as to write to Mr. Barre at the mint in Paris, extolling the quality of the coin punch with which I had supplied him, and left again with a promise to return the next day. —Then I went to Mr. K., a shareholder in a large ironworks, to whom my friend Mr. E. of Z. had been so kind as to commend me, as also to several other most excellent iron and steel manufacturers in the North of England. Mr. K. complained about the large number of punches that crack when tempered, and how even very dextrous workers have accidents with them. He then showed me one such punch, of a very low height, which in desperation they had sought to remedy by actually welding steel onto iron. This punch, of 2 inches in diameter and octagonal in shape, presumably because round forging would have opened it up in the middle, had been kept low that it might remain whole on tempering, though its thinness also meant that it did not last long.

I had a long conversation with Mr. K.’s son about the smelting of iron ore with anthracite and then again with coke, for as I said, he is himself a shareholder in
a large ironworks as well as being a highly skilled smelter who has already won a prize for his work. —I left with an invitation to come again whenever I wished and the assurance that his father would be delighted to make my acquaintance and to commend me to a large ironworks in Yorkshire, whose smelting with coke and cold blast (as opposed to the hot blast used with anthracite) produces very good iron. Remarking on my ability to express myself adequately on the subjects in question, or so it seemed to him, he was confident that I would be well received there. After leaving him I proceeded to an esteemed compatriot of mine, Mr. Imthurn on Fenchurch Street, and from there, on the off-chance that he might still be in London, went to call on my nephew Mr. A. Winz and family.

Mr. Imthurn and I talked for some time about the most pressing matter of the day in Schaffhausen, namely the means by which we might, with outside help, finance a railway line via Waldshut to Schaffhausen and from there to Konstanz.

The letter from Mr. Zündel explaining in detail the obvious advantages of building a railway along the above route that I had delivered to Mr. P. in Basel, having first made a copy of the same, I now handed over to
Mr. Imthurn, along with still more details of the planned undertaking, that they might be of service to him here in promoting the formation of a company for this purpose in England.

div.head: Fischer besucht das Patentamt, 23. Juli 1845
div.p:
After visiting Mr. Imthurn again, I returned to the mint, where Mr. Brande welcomed me as an old friend. Since he had already examined the sample punches that I had left there the day before, he placed an order for the same in steel, which he had hitherto procured from Huntsman, he said, albeit with uneven results. I now showed him the components of a percussion lock made of cast bar iron, which he found very interesting, and in answer to my question as to whether such a thing had ever been made in England remarked that not only did he not know of a single instance of it but it had long been deemed all but impossible. Just as we were beginning to talk in greater depth about this object that seemed to matter so much to him, two gentlemen arrived wishing to speak to him forthwith, whereupon he asked me to visit him again on my return from the north of England, which I had told him was where I intended to go next after leaving him. Having been given an incorrect house number, my long walk from the mint to Mr. Winz on Frederick Street Grays Inn Lane was all for nothing, and I was glad to have time
to visit the Register Office for Patent ApplicationsMöglicherweise besuchte Fischer Moses Poole in seinem privaten Patentbüro. and there acquaint the secretary, Mr. Poole, with my appendage of 2 caveats to the priority of two of my inventions, the one of which now reads:«for an alloy, proper to be mixed and fused with Pig-iron, Steel of every description, and also Bar or forged, or Scrape-iron;» and the other: «for a new way of making Horseshoes, and also Shoes for all other Kinds of Cattle».

He was very friendly, and as it seemed to him that I had not quite understood certain remarks of his, gave me a booklet about patent applications and how one must conduct oneself when making one, inviting me to come again the following day.

At this juncture I cannot help but remark on what a difference I noticed between this – one might almost call it – amiability and the unpolished manners and moroseness of many an official in other countries.

As it rained almost the whole day, and I had long errands to run, I took a cab, which cost me 2 sh. or 1 fl. 12 kr. per hour. —That occasioned me sufficient opportunity to see the dangers and disadvantages of London’s much vaunted wooden paving, which it seems that even the circumspect and scrupulous English have all too hastily adopted, as many of the most frequented streets in London
are now paved in this way. Whenever it rains, the filth composed of dust, horse dung, abraded wood and detritus of all kinds becomes as slippery as black ice so that coachmen and carriers – whose horses, owing to the stone-paved streets in between, naturally do not wear sharpened shoes for this purpose – are able to proceed only very slowly, yet still slide away and even fall from time to time. My coachman cursed the paving and said that in winter it was much worse.

Having covered such distances, some of them by cab, some on foot, I concluded the day with letters to my three sons, who are now established in Austria, telling them of my safe arrival in England and of the business affairs that occasioned the journey. I then had lunch, or rather supper, since it was after 7 o'clock by then, in a very genteel coffeehouse (the Post Office Coffeehouse), where for exactly the same spread, a meal with tea or coffee costs half what it does in the so-called hotels, where the luxuriousness of the interiors, as in the one in which I am currently residing, is excessive, but still has to be paid for by the guests.

div.head: Neveu Winz und hüttenmännisches Fachsimpeln mit Herrn K., 24. Juli 1845
div.p:
On the 24th, having obtained the correct address, I visited my nephew Mr. Winz and his family, but found him not at home, though I
was to meet him later at Mr. Im-Thurn’s, who kindly accompanied me to the Register Office. There, for a registration fee of 2 pounds and 2 shillings (25 fl. and 12 kr.) Mr. Poole entered my petition for two caveats in the protocol just as I had previously written them up and presented to him. On the way back I again called on Mr. K., to discuss with him some matters relating to the smelting of iron ore with anthracite and then again with coke, and with hot or cold blast. He told me that in general, smelting with anthracite is done with hot blast, the air for which has to pass through a system of siphons in which it is heated to a temperature at which lead would melt, while the anthracite, having had to make the long journey through a furnace shaft of 48 to 50 feet in height, has already turned to coke by the time it enters the smelting chamber, whereas if coke is used directly cold blast is applied.

He showed me a drawing of the blast furnace at Alfredton in DerbyshireMöglicherweise handelte es sich um Butterley Works., which 40 years previously the proprietor Wilkinson had introduced at the Bradley Bradley ironworks, but which since then had not received the attention, either in England or on the Continent, that the nature of it deserved. I soon afterwards had an opportunity to persuade myself of its most salient advantage
in the operation of a small cupola furnace fired with charcoal, which was blasted with air through not just one or two nozzles on opposite sides of the furnace, as is done here and there, but three of nozzles spaced apart in an equilateral triangle.

While in some places in England the stand for this is made of refractory brick, here the most excellent sandstone was used, as it was for the building itself. The iron obtained from smelting ore with coke was at any rate better, he said, though it was also dearer in most cases, since in his experience, 5 Centner of anthracite, converted into coke, weighed only 3¾ cwt, and 2½ cwt of coke was necessary to extract 1 cwt of pig iron from 35-per-cent ore. — My best source of information on this matter, he added, would be the Low Moor Ironworks, where they smelted with cold blast and coke, to which I was to convey a letter of his. The works of the Butlery Iron Company in which he himself had a stake, meanwhile, used anthracite and hot blast. Exactly how low and narrow a coke-fired blast furnace would have to be at its 3 principal diameters he could not say, though he was able to tell me where I might surely learn the same.

After dinner, which was at 5 o’clock in the afternoon,
I went for a walk through Cheapside and along Ludgate Hill as far as Fleet Street, where whatever wares it may contain, one store after another seeks to outdo all the others in abundance, variety, elegance, and indeed luxury, and where, quite apart from whatever else is to be found stacked up in other English cities, and quite apart from the thousands of ships that come and go, one is soon persuaded that this country really is the world’s marketplace answering the world’s demand.

As an example of this luxury, I shall mention a shop I saw that sells shawls, silks and such like fashion accessories. The said shop has ceilings twice the normal height, that is 18 feet, and its entrance takes the shape of an inward-pointing convex triangle, whose severed apex is the doorway. The 4 points on each side are the 4 brass columns, the spaces between which are filled by 4 mirrors, arranged to face each other so that what one actually sees are 8 panes of 18 feet in height and 3½ feet in width, behind which all the finest things are piled up in tiers. The inside walls, moreover, are likewise covered in mirrors, which at night, especially, when all the many gaslights are burning, makes for a most surprising sight on account of their being multiplied by all the many mirrors. This shop is located in the building called Gloucester House
on Ludgate Hill, which is owned by Harvey & Son. —I lingered for a long time in front of this magazine in which all the most precious of the aforementioned articles were assembled and amassed, but still have no idea how this profligate display might retain its interest, given how much competition there is from others.

div.head: Fischer und Neveu Winz besuchen die Polytechnical Institution, 25. Juli 1845
div.p: Today my route more than once took me past the statue of the Duke of Wellington erected two years ago, which shows him as a mounted general and whose oval plinth is inscribed solely with the name “Wellington”. Who modelled it and cast it I do not knowDer Künstler war Francis Leggatt Chantrey., but that the art of casting has brought forth a so-called patina or Aerugo nobilis (which normally is at once a result and marker of great age), while the gentleman himself is still alive seems to me to be a breach of decorum. No such error was made on the outstanding casts to be seen in Munich, apart from there where it served to make them more readily apparent or promised to show the accomplishment of the artist to better advantage than would a wholly dark silhouette. Whether the horse is too large and too fat in relation to the figure of Wellington I dare not say, as nothing could be further from my mind than to pretend to be a judge of art.

This morning, after a visit to the Patent Office, where I received the 2 caveats for my inventions from Mr.
Poole, I accompanied my nephew Mr. A. Winz to the Polytechnical Institution to see the curious objects that the arts and crafts of this country have lately brought forth, first and foremost among them the “working model” of the much talked-of, and, in respect of its practical utility, frequently and fiercely contested invention of the atmospheric railway set up there by Messrs. Samuda and Clegg. The new objects, most of them from the field of engineering, were so extremely numerous that it would have taken days just to inspect them properly, nor does space permit even a superficial enumeration of the same; suffice it to say, therefore, that only in England can something at once so great and so instructive be accomplished, since only a city that will soon number 1½ million inhabitants can supply enough inquiring minds for the admission tickets needed to cover the costs of this undertaking. Here, therefore, I shall mention only the small, I believe 1 horsepower steam engine that had to run constantly in order to work the air pump needed keep the tube, which is circa 60 foot long with an internal bore of about 5/4Zoll, or so it seemed to me, sufficiently emptied of air to drive the 5 little wagons hooked one behind the other, each of which had a seat for one person. The front wagon, of course,
was attached to the piston by means of a vertical rod. The rimmed tubes, moreover, each have a narrow opening or slit at the top that is opened only by the piston approaching from some distance away and then is closed again by special valves, thus ensuring that the said piston is always travelling through an airless and air-tight tube. This extremely fast railway was mounted on a 3-foot-high gantry running alongside a basin filled with water 14 feet deep, on which a little steamboat chugged around and a boy in a diving bell was dropped down to the bottom. —I must in all honesty confess that I arrived in England with quite a strong prejudice against atmospheric railways, doubting both their feasibility and what I imagined to be the manifold difficulties of maintaining a good, air-tight system capable of operating without interruption. Now that I have seen this model and the efficacy of the method – notwithstanding the small diameter of the tube – in action, however, and have learned that just such a railway, albeit not of any great length, has been running daily in Dublin at greater speeds than a conventional locomotive ever could and that the said railway is indeed used so that parliament, responding to the extremely favourable expert report on it,
will not object to a concession being granted to the company now wishing to run such a railway from Croydon to Brighton, a distance of 48 miles, which owing to the advanced state of the preparations for the same will be able to go into service very soon and whose shareholders will doubtless have verified the feasibility of every aspect of the venture, I have now changed my mind and believe that atmospheric railways will supplant or modify conventional locomotive-driven railways if not wholly, then at least in part. As it is worth making the effort to know the factors that speak both for and against this new invention, and to do so before it becomes part of our lives so that when that happens, it will become apparent from its constant success or want of success which side was the most right, I would like to devote some space to the pros and cons of this most important matter such as I have been able to ascertain during my stay here in England.

One principal objection that is made is that were there to be even the tiniest gap between the tubes and the piston and air pump being drawn along, as might happen very easily, the wagons would inevitably come to a standstill, as it would no longer be possible to create a vacuum.
Responding to this certainly legitimate objection, Messrs. Samuda and Clegg claim that the air pump, which has a diameter of 57½ Zoll, is powerful enough to render the iron pipes airless over their entire length, and the pressure gauges at either end at the same level, within just 5 to at most 6 minutes, so that even if air were to stream in through an imperceptible crack (a large one would be noticed immediately and could be refilled or another section of pipe inserted inside it so as not to occasion any great delay), the vacuum, though not complete, would still be sufficient to drive the piston, and with it the wagons, to the nearest station, which at worst would be ½ an English mile away (circa 5500 feet) – and at an acceptable speed, too, especially if, as could be easily enough accomplished, the number of piston strokes set in motion by the air pump were multiplied by a steam engine. Having arrived at the station, a new system of pipes would commence, as it does in any case at one-mile intervals. —

The second principal objection is the cost. This was likewise countered by the assertion, supported by a detailed calculation published in the Times illustrated, that the installation and operation of an atmospheric railway would cost less than ⅔ of what a railway run with conventional locomotives costs. To delve into the details
of this calculation would be going too far here, though it seems to me that this is a matter of great importance to railway entrepreneurs, since one cannot presume to present obviously incorrect information to a public such as that in England, where competent judges abound.

The day’s business ended quite early with the purchase of various items and packing for tomorrow’s departure for Leeds, 205 miles hence, the train for which leaves from Euston Station, which is itself some miles away from the City of London, where I am currently residing.

div.head: London–Leeds, 26. Juli 1845
div.p:
For a fare of 2 shillings a cab took me all the way to Euston Station, where for a seat in the second class to Leeds I had to pay 1 pound and 15 shillings or 18 fl. in Reichsgeld. The train departed at 11 o’clock in the morning. Notwithstanding the 20 stops and more en route with just enough time for people to get on and off, and that we were held up in Weldon for 5 and in Derby for 25 minutes, so that we might eat some lunch, we still arrived in Leeds at half past 6 that evening, meaning that the astonishing distance of 205 English or 41 German miles, which translates into a rate of 12 miles per hour or twenty-four Wegstunden, was overcome at a speed such as I have encountered nowhere else. It is all but impossible to observe anything at such a speed, though from time to time, there where the terrain by chance afforded an expansive view,
not far from Coventry where the hay was being brought in, I did have an opportunity to do so; it was a most instructive sight, revealing how with just one horse and one man, mown grass might be swiftly and evenly distributed over a very large meadow that it might dry all the faster. —For the horse was hitched to a hollow wooden cylinder of some 8 feet in length and 4 feet in diameter. This consisted of nothing but laths, which were spaced about 10 to 12 inches apart and nailed onto the two base plates or discs at either end. These in turn had an axle passing through them, attached to whose protruding hubs, as on a clover roller, were the two inward-pointing shafts that formed the traces for the horse. The cylinder was filled with mown hay through a hatch in the roller, like that on a cylindrical coffee roaster only with slits. Once the hatch was closed, the man had the horse set off whereupon the cylinder rotated so that every time one of the openings was facing downwards some of the mown grass fell out of it, always across the full length of the slit and always at the same distance from the previous one, until finally the cylinder was empty and had to be refilled.

The passenger carriages were fitted with something very sensible that I have so far seen nowhere else except in England: namely three round apertures in the ceiling, which on the outside are shielded with a bell or cap made of iron sheet,
whose side walls in turn have around 9 slits in them so as to promote the circulation of air without troubling the passengers, as when cold weather or rain or storms make it necessary to keep all the windows shut. At night, the middle of the three apertures is fitted with a lantern, since the trains in England run both day and night.

The optical illusion of the crooked spire of Chesterfield, which I reported in my earlier diary, delighted me all over again, as did the farmers’ pretty little windmills, which turn into the wind all by themselves, and each one of which supplies as much flour on average as any large household might need. Almost all the cuttings along the railway from London to Leeds are through first marl and then limestone, the strata and fissures of the more northerly areas bearing a certain resemblance to the Swabian Alb. Despite being tended with great care, the fruits of the field were far behind, and nowhere near as fine as in France or at home. Another peculiarity that warrants mention is that on 26th July, all the women in the carriage were wearing fur collars around their necks and were wrapped in shawls.

As I said, I arrived in Leeds after 6 o’clock in the evening and took lodgings at the White Horse Hotel. —In the dining room, a gentleman clad all in black had no sooner entered than he lay down, dirty boots and all, on the very fine canapé.
Yet no one said a word, not even when he had a tobacco pipe brought to him that he might smoke in that very same attitude, which was all that had hitherto been missing to demonstrate the kind of man he was. Eighteen years had passed since my last visit to England, and I had imagined that since so much else had changed in the way of transport and domestic interiors, then surely many of the customs and habits and the way people dressed would have changed, too, only this was not the case. Foreigners make little impression on these taciturn, obdurate islanders, and too few of them ever reach the interior in any case. And should those that do become too bumptious, as so many peddlers of wisdom are prone to do with us good-natured Swiss, here they are simply ridiculed, or, better still, treated with utter contempt. The Englishman knows very well what he wants and what he can and is proud and ambitious, though he does not advertise this, unlike certain other people who just love to adorn themselves in whatever scraps of glory they can scrape together.

To return to the tobacco-smoking: I had imagined that since this nasty habit had made such alarming progress on the Continent these past few years, it could not be otherwise than that the English would likewise have found it impossible to resist; yet that was not the case at all. I believe I am not mistaken in this,
and gladly cite persons who have recently returned from England and report that among a thousand male persons of all classes one will find scarcely a single tobacco smoker.

div.head: Betrachtungen zum Verkehr in England, 27. Juli 1845
div.p:
—The whole day was taken up with writing and the evening with a walk, although it was very windy and cold, and with inquiries into stage-coaches that might be leaving for Bradford, a small town 26 miles from Leeds, on the morrow, say, that being a Sunday, which in Leeds is observed even more sombrely than in London, making it impossible to visit anyone. I was told that I might leave for Bradford on any one of the ten departures that day. This uncommonly frequent service to all sorts of places and with it the circulation of people, and hence of money, is a consequence of the extraordinary network of railways that has already spread out all over England, and of being able to travel from Euston-Station near London to the north of England within just 24 hours, there being 12 trains both day and night as well as 2 “extra trains”. Consequently, there have to be stage-coaches on hand to bring those arriving and departing from the station to their destinations, which may be 10 or even 20 miles hence. — To return to the Sabbath, I noticed that not until 7 o’clock in the evening did large numbers of people of every age and sex come out of the church, even as a Methodist preacher on the market square
was preaching most fervently down from his perch to the rapt crowd below.

div.head: Low Moor Ironworks, 28. Juli 1845
div.p: Today, exactly 14 days after my departure from home, I was to see a member of the family again, and there, where 30 years ago, at almost exactly the same time of year, I enjoyed such friendship as would be repeated, always with the same warmth, on all my later visits to England, as outlined in my diaries of those trips.

I knew by then that old Mr. Gott had died some years previously, but was received in the customary manner by his son, Mr. John Gott, whom I met betimes in the counting houseEs ist unklar, ob Fischer die Familie Gott an ihrer Wohnaddresse in 27 Guildford Street oder einen ihrer beiden Fabriken Armley Mill oder Park Mill aufsuchte.. He immediately invited me to dine with him at his spendid country seat near Kirkdale, 3 miles from Leeds, which I politely declined on the grounds that I wished to visit the large ironworks at Low Moor, which had been commended to me most warmly. —“Both are possible, my friend”, said he; “just come to me, and I shall appoint one of my clerks to drive you to the place [here he glanced at the clock], where in just a few minutes you will be met by the Kutsche that will take you to Bradford. There, take a cab or gig to Low Moor, which is 3 miles hence, and be sure to have him wait ready to take you back to Bradford afterwards. You can then take the 4 o’clock coach back to Leeds, and since we dine at around 6 o’clock or later, you
will be back just in time to join us, my country seat being hard by Kirkdale, as you know.” I could not object to any of this, and as the old counting house clerk had already taken his hat down off its hook, I commended myself and left. “I was very glad to see you again”, said the clerk, once outside the door and on the street. “I recognized you right away, though 18 years have passed since you were last with us.” I, too, remembered him, and being told of the then still secret method of using a solution of caoutchouc to render cloth water-proof.

On arriving at the inn, I scarcely had time to go inside since the coach was just about to depart. —The road from Leeds to Bradford leads past Kirkdale (an Old English or rather Anglo-Saxon word, Kirchthal in German), not far from which, situated in a park-like setting on a pretty little hill grown over with oaks and other deciduous trees, is Mr. Gott’s splendid country seat. From there, one looks out onto the fine ruins, some of them with their forms intact and charmingly overgrown with ivy and other plants, of one of the monasteries destroyed under Henry VIII which gave this area its name, and which owing to its many factories, ironworks and coal mines is now full of activity so that one passes by fields,
villages and individual houses of the most varied appearance.

Not far outside Leeds, and then without interruption as far as Low Moor, I saw still more of the extraordinary industry of the English: for scattered along the edge of the country road were blocks that were somewhat prismatic in shape and that owing to their play of colours I would have taken for marble, had they not been so lavishly glazed over. Later I saw some people working at these blocks, busily breaking them up for use as road-building material, whereupon I realised that this must be slag from a blast furnace at a nearby ironworks, which to obtain a certain quantity of the same for processing, and to facilitate and expedite its loading and unloading, is evidently run off into iron crates. These are shaped as described above so that the 10-Centner-heavy mass might fall out of them all the more easily and be ground up for use in lieu of gravel, which perhaps does not occur naturally in this region, making iron slag the best material that can be had for this purpose. Arriving in Bradford at around 12 o’clock, I took a gig (a two-wheeled chaise) at the Sun Inn staging post, and had him drive me to Low Moor, which to judge by the name I imagined to be on the valley floor, as indeed it was. —But the smoke from the 4 blast furnaces, the long row of coking ovens,
where small lumps of anthracite are passed through cylindrical sieves to separate them from the larger pieces and then coked inside closed chambers stoked by women, and the long coking lines, where the large but not necessarily excellent anthracite is coked in the customary way, as well as from the refining, puddling and bloom furnaces and the annealing furnaces for the hammer and rolling mills made it impossible to take in the site of several acres in size and criss-crossed all over with railways bearing wagons solely for its own use in its entirety. On entering the same, or rather the “porter’s lodge”, my horse, at my request, was immediately unhitched and taken to a stable without my being pestered with probing questions as to who I was or where I had come from and what I wanted etc., as happens elsewhere. On the contrary, I was promptly assigned a young man who was to escort me to the owner of the works. Mr. Dawson, as the said gentleman was called, read the letter that I had handed to him and then, being somewhat unsteady on his feet, seized his hat and stick and took me on a 2-hour tour of the whole works, starting with the charcoaling and then proceeding to the blast furnaces and the foundry, in which much to my astonishment they still had reverberating furnaces, though they were used only for very particular purposes, he told me; presumably to cast rollers, which, nota bene, they make themselves,
and for which they do not use a cupola furnace, since such a furnace would be unlikely to produce such very fine and very hard results. From there we went to the other aforementioned furnaces and to the bellows driven by two steam engines of 160 horsepower each. This supplies the cold blast used for all the furnaces here, since hot blast does not work for blast furnaces fired by coke, they tell me, though it does for those fired by anthracite. The blast pressure here is just 3½ pounds per [square foot]«Quadratfuss» im Erstdruck als Piktogramm dargestellt., which is saying a lot. — What interested me in particular about this works, and demonstrates how readily the English adopt whatever works in practice, was its use of a discovery made by that genius Perkins. — Perkins, of course, is an American, and as he himself told me 18 years ago, used to work as a goldsmith in Washington. There he found that even the hardest English file might be cut in twain using no more than a very thin disc of soft iron sheet, as long as the said disc was clamped into a lathe or something similar and rotated extremely fast. This method was being applied here on a large scale, where two such discs of circa 3 feet in diameter and spaced far enough apart (I would guess about 10 feet) were attached to the same drive shaft and kept rigid and upright by
thick iron counterplates reaching up to 8 inches from the edge. These discs then rotate uncommonly fast. The finished rail rolls out of the rolling mill and, if somewhat bent, is laid out on a long and completely flat iron plate to be hammered straight with a wooden mallet before being pushed against the spinning discs and so cut asunder by the same, as if it were mere wood. Underneath, the discs pass through a trough fed by a constant stream of cold water to keep them cool.

The location is as favourable as it could possibly be for the operation of an ironworks. It is close to major cities, most notably Leeds, and is surrounded by mineshafts from which not just limestone, but also anthracite and iron ore are extracted; and as the headgear for the mineshaft is at a higher elevation than the works, the railway wagons loaded with these materials can slowly roll down the incline towards it, the gradient being such that they move of their own accord without ever gaining too much speed, and so arrive at their destination, where they are unloaded ready to be pulled back up the hill by a horse on a different set of rails. Thanks to the coincidence of these circumstances, Mr. Dawson told me, a Centner of anthracite, which is 112 English pounds in weight, supplied to the charcoaling, or rather coking, plant costs less than a penny, or 2½ kr. Reichsvaluta, to be more exact. The iron ores are poor, yielding only
25 per cent iron, and have to be roasted before they can be stoked into the blast furnace. The limestone flux is added at a rate of 25 pounds per cwt extracted iron, meaning 6 pounds per cwt ore. As for coal, 3 cwt coke is required per cwt of pig iron to be run off, that is, 75 pounds per cwt of ore, which seems a lot to me. If the ratios of anthracite were reduced, one would need 120 pounds of anthracite per cwt, that is, circa 480 pounds for every cwt of smelted pig iron. The pig iron produced here is a fine grey colour, but not always of an even grain. Samples are therefore taken of every tapping, and are duly numbered, as is the tapping itself, which forms a grate consisting entirely of small wedges like those used in a cupola furnace. The English are indeed much more conscientious about delivering iron of a consistently high quality to their consumers than are many iron masters on the Continent. But they also know from experience how much, in every respect, depends on the quality of the iron; and those who are familiar with how difficult it is to produce good bar iron with coke or anthracite will not be surprised at the care taken with this, and indeed with the whole process as well, from the resmelting of the pig iron, to the fine iron, the puddling and the welding off, and still more treatment after that such as I never saw elsewhere,
the result of which is the most excellent iron made with coke that I have ever seen, even though it is sold dearer than all the others too. —It was time to return to Leeds, and I took my leave of Mr. Dawson, who had honoured the letter commending me to him by being most accommodating, providing me with not only the detailed explanations I desired but also samples of ore, limestone, coal, coke and iron at all stages of production, from pig iron to finished bar iron, for which I thanked him most heartily.

div.head: Abendgesellschaft in der Villa Gott, 28. Juli 1845
div.p: The post coach from Halifax to Leeds arrived in Bradford at 4 o’clock and at 6 o’clock I was at Mr. Gott’s country seat.

As he had not yet returned from town, a footman led me into a room where I might perform my toilet – which indeed was not unnecessary since I was returning from the bosom of an ironworks where one is constantly enveloped in a cloud of smoke, coal dust and steam – and bade me await his master in the library. With its exquisitely bound works both ancient and modern, its fine paintings and engravings, its busts of Carrara marble standing on columns of coloured marble with white pedestals and furnishings of a piece, this room was a haven for the mind of anyone seeking respite from the travails of daily business.

The arrangement of three stuffed night owls standing sentinel in front of the great mirror did not betray the purpose of their being there, and naturally I was loath to ask it of Mr. Gott when he later came to fetch me and take me to the reception room, where 4 more gentlemen and 5 ladies were present. On entering the highly ornate dining room shortly after seven o’clock, we sat down, waited on by three footmen as well as the “butler”, to a most splendid dinner, which I, despite having gone for 12 hours with nothing but a little marshmallow tea procured for me by an apothecary in Bradford, could not enjoy. Being hoarse and unwell owing to a cold that I had caught while still in London, and with a medicine bottle in my pocket, I had to take care not to make matters worse and had to leave the many glasses of wine of all kinds served by the said butler untouched before me. After the ladies had withdrawn, as is customary here, the gentlemen remained seated for drinks and to discuss matters of interest to them, and it did not take long before the conversation turned to railways. As Mr. Gott told me that he was very interested in this matter and would be accompanying an engineer to the site of a new branch line the very next morning, I felt myself at liberty to raise the project for a railway from Basel to Schaffhausen and Konstanz, and to
urge upon him the importance of the favourable lay of the land, noting that to execute our plans we would nevertheless need outside capital since our own powers would not be sufficient to the task. —During dinner, it had seemed to me that I had seen the gentleman sitting opposite me somewhere before. With the ladies absent, we were now much closer to each other than hitherto, and when Mr. Gott suddenly cried out: “But let us hear what your compatriot has to say about this!” I immediately went over to him and discovered that it was Mr. Bischof of Basel, with whom I had become acquainted some 18 or 20 years earlier, again as a friend of Mr. Gott. I was glad to be able to appeal to him in this or that matter, and he confirmed everything that I had hitherto asserted. —The footman then came to summon us into the tea room, leaving me with just enough time to ask Mr. Gott to ponder the matter and promising to write to him about it in due course. —As is well known, nowhere does one drink better tea, and with such circumstance, as one does in England. Though I had been foregoing this beverage for many years in the belief that it prevented me sleeping, here it proved a true elixir, since being unwell I had for several days been afflicted with the most terrible thirst. At the back of this tea room, which with its exquisite furnishings, wonderfully fragrant flowers and
hot-house plants, its windows reaching almost down to the ground and glass doors giving onto the garden, might more properly be called a tea salon, was an organ reaching almost to its very high ceiling. In the middle stood a large, round table of acajou laid out with newspapers, the lithographs of the day and pamphlets illustrating the various phases in the marriage of Mr. Caudle & his Wife. Thanks to the typically English spirit of invention and improvement, the “changeable faces of Mistress Caudle” could be made to change by pulling a string attached to the back of the engraving that her physiognomy better fit the scene depicted. This is a device that the English clearly delight in, since one sees it displayed for sale in print shops everywhere at present.—Finally, to complete my description of this room, I have to note that on the day I was there, the 28th July, there was a fire blazing in the hearth and that on leaving the house and stepping outside, one really did have the impression that the corn was becoming greener rather than yellower. —At around 10 o’clock I took my leave of Mr. Gott and the assembled company, which at that moment was taking coffee, and took the cab standing in front of the house to Leeds, some 3 miles hence.

div.head: Fischer schreibt einen Brief an seine Enkelin, 29. Juli 1845
div.p:
Almost the whole day was taken up with writing a long letter to Mr. Gott and making a copy of the same, as well as
a letter to my granddaughter Mathilde so that my family back home will know where in the world I have got to, and concluded with my walking over to Mr. Gott's counting house and taking a stroll through that part of town.

The character of this city, which by the way is very large, is quite different from that of London. The general affluence and cleanliness of even the outlying streets, which is what we should apply as our measure, seems to me to be greater. Here, everyone who has hands works and earns a living by them. The textile mills and flax spinning mills are all flourishing, and the many obelisks here, by which I mean the smoke stacks for the steam engines and smelters that have multiplied so astonishingly and in some instances are 60 to 80 feet tall, are of greater benefit here than were their forebears in Egypt, and when seen from a distance lend the city a very distinctive aspect. Except for the cabs and omnibuses to the station and the post coaches to the surrounding villages, there are not many people out riding or being driven, whereas the shops for the most part are attractive, and some of them well stocked.

div.head: Betrachtungen zum Eisenbahnwesen, 30. Juli 1845
div.p:
Having spent almost the whole day writing, since the rainy weather that is more frequent in England at this time of year did not permit us to go outside, I instead went through Bradshaw’s Railway and Steam-Navigation-Guide,
which I had purchased while in London. I was astonished at how wide-ranging and detailed the information about railways and steamships contained in this book actually is, and not just in relation to England but to other countries, too, those furthest afield from London being Alexandria, Constantinople and Petersburg. And when one takes out the map of England and Scotland – all that is shown of Ireland is the coastline and the distances of the various passages to England – and surveys the railways that have already been built, and even more so those that are in planning or for which concessions have been granted and in some cases are already being built, one no longer knows what to think or how one should imagine this song ending or where all the people who are to ride on these railways are to come from? —It is inevitable, I believe, that once the high-water mark has been reached, that is, once this railway-building has been taken to an extreme, a great crisis will ensue, after which only those railways (to say nothing of today’s locomotives, which given the current spirit of invention might easily be supplanted and rendered obsolete by some happily conceived and executed idea from one day to the next) will survive that run there where there is a natural need for them, namely those that operate from city to city, where there has been passenger and goods traffic for centuries and consequently
a demand. There will certainly have to be major reforms of how they operate if they are to pay off, for after comparing how they run here with those on the Continent, it seems to me that the number of personnel in relation to the number of journeys is very limited indeed (since to judge by the listings in Bradshaw, the trains run day and night with twenty departures every 24 hours). This explains why I have seen far fewer railwaymen’s cottages and fewer station-masters than elsewhere. Either the Englishmen are, or believe themselves to be, more sure of themselves, or, given the unusual speed with which one travels here, they would not be able to heed the warning signals early enough in any case; or perhaps the telegraph lines running parallel to the railway might be used for signalling, though that seems improbable to me. One would expect these railways, through which people’s paths are crossing as never before, to make us more convivial; but of the eleven gentlemen in the dining room this evening, not one of them spoke a single word, unless it was with the attendant.

div.head: Reise nach Sheffield und Besuch eines alten Bekannten, 31. Juli 1845
