div.p:
My business in Leeds concluded, I once again visited Mr. Gott to discuss with him the probability, given how important connections by land and sea now are, of my finding in England a company that might be inclined to join the shareholders from Switzerland and Baden that are investing in the – incidentally very short
railway line from Basel via Waldshut to Schaffhausen and Constanz, and to remind him of the contents of the letter that I wrote him the day before yesterday, whereupon I received from him the assurance that he would write to me should such an occasion arise, and that if there were any other courtesy he might show me, he would do so most gladly. After receiving this renewed attestation of his friendship, I left Leeds at 1 o’clock on the branch line to Sheffield, where I arrived at 3 o’clock. After first having lunch I set off to visit my old acquaintance Mr. Sanderson. With 36 smelters and 6 cementation furnaces with which to convert Swedish iron ore into steel before smelting, Sanderson & Comp. are the largest makers of cast steel in Sheffield.

Just as I had imagined, I was greeted very amicably by old Mr. Sanderson, with whom I had made the journey from Chesterfield to Sheffield 20 years earlier, and was promptly taken on a tour of the whole works, which they certainly do not do with every guest.

We went first to the cementation furnaces, one of which had only just recently been fired up, while the other was going at full tilt. Each of these furnaces had two chests filled with circa 160 Centner of Dannemora iron, and three fires. This means that the flames
reverberate first in front of the chests, then in between them, and then up the rear wall, coming together again under the arch, where there are flues up into the chimney. Mr. Sanderson let me pull out a so-called eye, that is a plug of fireproof clay in the front wall of the furnace, that I might observe the play of the flames and the degree of heat inside the furnace, which it seemed to me had not yet reached its highest point, appearances being very deceptive whether the weather is fine or gloomy. From there we proceeded to the steel foundry, where nothing has changed these past twenty years – I might even say in the 50 years since Huntsman got his factory going. The furnaces are the same, the crucibles are the same, and they are filled and loaded both cold and hot, the only difference being the funnel used in the latter case. —The pouring was done with great care. Of the two first crucibles to be poured (each furnace has 2 crucibles containing circa 30 to 35 pounds of steel), one had a small hole and was more than half-emptied, whereupon the pourer quite sensibly poured off the remainder into the other crucible, since none of the crucibles, all of which have a flat and heavy lid, is truly full when it comes out of the furnace. The steel in this topped-up crucible was then carefully poured off in a thin and steady trickle into the middle of the
iron sprue. The two crucibles inside the second furnace, which was opened immediately afterwards, were both good and were poured off in the same way. The pouring involves three men: the first lifts out the crucible and carries it to the sprues half-buried in a pit, the second holds it steady with his tongs, while the third uses a sharp crowbar to prize off the lid and a small trowel to skim off the bits of slag floating on top. As there were several baskets of coke standing next to the smelters, I asked Mr. Sanderson how much coke he would need to smelt a Centner of steel, which he was able to tell me exactly. Believing that I had not understood him correctly, however, I repeated the question, to which he gave exactly the same answer as before. Now I was satisfied. When I told him the average consumption in my ironworks, he cried out: “You beat us! You beat us! You beat us!” One of the reasons, among many other, equally important ones, that I gave him as a possible cause of their high coke consumption he acknowledged as valid right away.
Being still unwell, I did not pay any further visits today and concluded the day with the usual note-taking.

div.head: Turton, Huntsman und chinesischer Tee, 1. August 1845
div.p:
August 1st. —Sheffield is a more attractive town than Leeds and the surrounding countryside on one side of it is almost like Switzerland. It also seems more populous to me and to have even more
lavishly stocked shops with even more luxuries in their windows than in Leeds. But owing to the thousands of columns of black smoke that are constantly being replenished by the carts full of anthracite and coke pulling up in front of them, anyone wanting to survey its incredible Vulcan works from above would have to await a fine Sunday. Today, after paying my compliments to Messrs. T..... & S.., Manufacturers of Cast Steel and Files, I wanted to visit Huntsman’s hammer mill, which is located next to a bridge over the River Don. TODO Nähnadelfabrik besuchen, und wegen einem Gedanken, der mir beigefallen, noch einmal mit Herrn Sanderson sprechen.
I went first to Mr. T....., where it seemed to me that my visit was embarrassing inasmuch as my name apparently meant nothing to them, as one of the gentlemen there told me. After exchanging a few compliments, therefore, I quickly took my leave. I was already at the gates through which the workshops and the counting house are reached (all the factories here are completely walled in and enclosed) when one of the gentlemen came after me and said that though I had surely seen similar factories, he would gladly show me his if I wished to see it. I accepted his offer out of politeness, but at the same time felt bound to show him, by the various remarks that I made both in the file smithy and, even more so, in the steel foundry, where the smelting foreman visibly pricked up his ears,
that nothing of what they were showing me was either alien or new to me. —I was thereupon given some pieces of crucible with the clay used to make them and the material they add to new crucibles to make them break like porcelain and protect them against the corrosion of coke. I must say, incidentally, that I liked the way they did the actual smelting. Their ingots often had a depression on top, meaning that quite a lot had to be knocked off them at times; the coke consumption of an identically (and incorrectly) fitted furnace was somewhat lower than Mr. Sanderson’s, though the coke was dearer by 1 shilling per ton, costing 15 instead of 14 shillings.

That in England, where everything else is optimised, smelting should be lagging so far behind so that the maximum heat needed can be reached only when the ambient air is dry and cold is surprising; the most likely reason for this stability is on the one hand the cheapness of the fuel, and on the other the fact that the actual smelting is done by the smelters, whereas the gentlemen or factory owners attend only to the profits; and as their growing sales make these substantial indeed, they become so rich that they do not have to dream up new methods for that purpose, still less introduce them.
Their steel smelters as they are now can hardly be used to smelt pure bar iron without any carbon-containing additives or platinum, as I have done in mine, the proof of which, as mentioned earlier, I brought with me to England and just prior to the time of writing presented not only to Mr. Brande, but also to Mr. Gott and Mr. K.

Mr. T..... was so kind as to give me directions to a needle factory, though what I had believed to be there, namely a wire-drawing works, I did not find since that establishment is apparently located some miles outside Sheffield. The manufacture of such a small but important object was nevertheless interesting to see, even if one finds detailed descriptions of this same production process in various technological journals. Seeing the thousands of needles lying all at sixes and sevenses being shaken on an iron shovel to make them fall into line so that eventually they were all pointing in the same direction was a true pleasure. The beating and piercing of the eyes, the sharpening of the points, during which the grinding stone, which the “foreman” told me rotates at a rate of several hundred revolutions per minute, disappeared behind a dense shower of sparks, the annealing of the needles in oil and their fine polishing thereafter have, as I said, been adequately described elsewhere, though there was much to attract me in watching these various operations.
It is but a small part of human activity and endeavour, but how good it is that men, guided by what is practical and necessary, have applied themselves even to this business as one that is of real benefit to mankind, and how pathetic do those levellers of our times with their abysmal ideas look by comparison!

Wishing to acquaint oneself with a city, and form a judgement of it in the space of just a few days, or even just a few hours, would be presumption bordering on the ridiculous; though to capture a few salient characteristics and summarise these can never be without interest.

Here, therefore, I shall present only the one or other thing worthy of note that struck me on my morning and afternoon walks to all the many corners of this very industrious city, and leave it to others to comment as they see fit.

Opposite the inn where I was residing (Tontine house) there was a certain Mr. Schweppe (doubtless of German origin) who was selling a “Celestial Polishing Powder”. On entering his shop I asked whether this powder might be applied to anything, and was told that yes, it might, though I forgot to inquire what kind of an effect it might have on certain people. —At the top of the same house were huge golden letters, almost two full stories high, with each word written below the other, as the Chinese are wont to do with their writing,
but saying nothing more than Old N. 12, which presumably was the name of a once popular inn. There was also a large mirror-glass panel, inscribed on which in gold lettering were all the many sorts of beers, wines and liquor served there, including “funeral wines”. Whether the said “funeral wines”, like their ordinary equivalents, cheered the hearts of the bereaved doubtless depends on the circumstances under which they are actually consumed.

The shops of the “ironmongers”, a trade somewhere between ironware and quincaillerie, are incredibly numerous and well-stocked, as only in Sheffield and Birmingham they would be. Among the many pieces they have on display are several of which I, at least, have neither a need, nor any notion or inkling of how they might be put to use. The English are such great speculators and so eager to save time for themselves and others that at a tanner’s shop I found foot measures, lasts and all manner of iron and steel tools such as are needed by shoemakers, so that such a one might procure everything needed to set up shop right here in this one place, without going a single step further. The tanner sold wrought and cast iron shoe tacks of all kinds, too, and as a curiosity to take home with me, I purchased
¼ pound of the latter, 200 of them altogether, for which I paid 1 penny or 3 kr. in our money.

This really is astonishing, though to defend the honour of Austrian industry, it must also be acknowledged that it has done something even more incredible, the town of Steyer being officially on record as having sold a dozen razorblades, which for religious reasons the Turks use only once even though each blade is furnished with its own case, as are all such razors, for just 22 kr. = 26 2/5 Rolta. —Indeed, products from all over the world are brought to market in England, and I am not even talking of how last week London was “flooded”, as it were, with glorious “pine-apples”, a whole shipload of this one fruit having arrived there from New Providence, but rather of the sale, also in London, of “Indian pale ale”, which also enjoys the approbation of the local physicians.

I lingered longest in front of the tea shops. Now that this curious country has been opened up to English trade, one sees all sorts of objects from there, but specifically tea chests of 1 to 2 cubic feet in content and adorned all over with paintings. These would have required captions, of course, though much of what they show is understandable even without any. There were combat scenes, games, judicial proceedings, religious ceremonies, music and performances on stringed instruments,
some of which resemble our own, though most are quite different, as well as scenes of domestic life. Especially disgraceful, however, are the feet, and of Chinese of both sexes, moreover, which are thicker at the bottom than at the top and not elongated by toes. Instead they are squeezed together to make them look rounded, like the feet of an elephant.

The task that I had set myself for today was to visit the hammer mill of the Huntsman steel foundry, which like every factory here is walled in, but is built in a manner that makes it quite unlike any other hammer mill in the world, being as similar to a medieval castle as one egg is to another.

Although Mr. Huntsman himself was not present, I was immediately let in, having not only told the foreman who I was, but having also asked him to thin out, for a fee, a piece of my own steel with my own name inscribed upon it, which I had brought with me from Schaffhausen for this very purpose.

All that I was wondering was whether Mr. Huntsman, with whom I had stood in this very same hammer mill 20 years previously, had in the meantime made any changes to either the feed system or the style of the heating furnace, which turned out to be the case, in that he now had better control of the whole process and the furnace had been adapted to the use of anthracite and coke.
The steam hammer itself, however, is not exemplary, as the travel of the hammers is not proportionate, the larger ones being too slow and the smaller ones too fast. As their pathways, moreover, are too wide and flat, each piece can be heated only briefly. This is no concern of theirs, however, since whatever does not become long or thin enough when heated is simply returned to the heating furnace, in which there are always plenty of pieces waiting to be stretched. While the English are masters of rolling, I did not see a single good steam hammer such as we have in Germany and Switzerland.
My day ended with my purchasing a few items, including a case bearing the Latin inscription Multum in parvo, and with packing, at least provisionally, for my departure on the morrow.

div.head: Sheffield–London, 2. August 1845
div.p:
August 2nd. — At Mr. Sanderson’s request, I returned to his factory at 9 o’clock in order to discuss with him an object to which he quite rightly attaches great importance. After taking my leave of him and, in my haste, enjoying a lunch of just a few cold cuts with bread and beer, I left Sheffield at 1 o’clock in the afternoon so as to reach London, which is 165 miles away, by 7 o’clock that evening. —The journey as far as Rugby was extremely unpleasant because attached to the tail end of the long train was a so-called “propeller” (a locomotive that pushes while the front one pulls). This caused so much lurching
that one young lady became quite sick. This highly dangerous mode of locomotion will probably be abolished by an act of parliament. One of England’s first mechanical engineers expressed his own opinion of it by remarking that if one pushes against a rope that is lying completely straight, it will inevitably bend and veer off course no matter how thick it is, whereas if it is merely pulled from the front, it will always remain completely straight. Ordinarily there are just 2 stations over a distance of 200 English miles at which the train stops briefly and where there is a sign saying “Refreshments are to be had.” —Amazingly, one is then given what is not served anywhere else in England: soup, that is to say, a thick, meaty broth with some toasted bread that one has to crumble into it. A plate of such a soupy broth, however, costs 36 kr.

We arrived in London at 7 o’clock in the evening – safe and well, thank God, since it seems to me that not everything, be it the safety of the journeys or the provisioning of the passengers and other goods, is handled as carefully as it is in Austria and Bavaria, where such things are done much more conscientiously. With such a vast number of locomotives, “trains” and wagons loaded with goods, cattle and other objects, one can only marvel at it all, and can hardly conceive of the capital that has had to be invested in these gigantic undertakings, from Dover all the way to Edinburgh.
Where it comes from or where it goes is impossible to say, for notwithstanding all of this, the rich are rich and the poor are poor, and the social conditions have not visibly changed, except that everything now seems more abundant and more splendid than it was before. On the other hand, one is bound to wonder, walking through the streets at night, where the gaslights are lit and the brightly illuminated shop fronts afford the eager eye an unbroken, mile-long row of treasures of all kinds, and where one sees people busy about their work and the thousands upon thousands of conveyances of all kinds, to say nothing of the boats covering the whole Thames – as I say, one is bound to wonder, seeing all this, how long we can continue to climb, and what may cause us to reach our culmination point, which, as with all earthly undertakings, is undoubtedly coming, be it in the near or distant future?
The cab that took me from the Euston terminus, which is a long way from the centre of town, to the lodgings I took 20 years ago at St. Pauls Family Hotel, cost me just 1 shilling.

div.head: Letzte Geschäfte in London, 3. August 1845
div.p:
This morning after church I had intended to visit my nephew Mr. August Wintz, but from his landlord learned that he and his family had already
departed for Switzerland the previous Thursday; may he arrive safely in Schaffhausen!

Although Sundays are no longer spent as quietly as they were in the past, which alone on account of the operation of the railways now straddling the whole kingdom would no longer be possible in any case, given the astonishing amount of traffic they set in motion, the difference compared to France is nonetheless striking. When I travelled from Paris to Calais fourteen days ago, we passed through villages in which there were builders laying bricks, carpenters sawing timber and farmers spreading manure on their fields; no one seemed to care that it was a Sunday. I also ran into people who may well have been to church that day, though one sees very few of them. Today at lunch I had the magnificent facade of St. Paul’s Church before me, barely 100 paces hence, and studying that artistic feat of architecture that vies with St. Peter’s in Rome, I noticed what seemed to me to be such a violation of symmetry, which surely should be the Conditio sine qua non in such a building, that I cannot imagine how any discerning Englishman with an eye for trivia could have failed to notice it, since it stares one so in the face. The frontispiece supported by colonnades is flanked by two, not very high towers, high up on whose anterior facades are two round
oculi, of which the one on the tower on the right when facing the portal is filled with a clock dial, whereas the equivalent oculus on the left has been left open, serving only crows and bats as a convenient entrance and exit. Did wealthy London not have enough money for a second clock? Or could not the hole at least have been filled and adorned with something appropriate? —Spent the afternoon writing and procuring this and that ready for tomorrow’s departure.

div.head: Besuch von Faraday und Reise nach Dover, 4. August 1845
div.p: August 4th — Today I went to take my leave of Mr. Im-Thurn and thence to Mr. Faraday at the Royal Institution. I considered myself most fortunate to find him once again in London, he having returned there from a recreational visit to France just a few days previously. Our conversation turned primarily on the invention and introduction of the electric telegraph, which one sees so frequently running parallel to the railway, and on the expansion of which this fine idea might yet be capable.

He inspected the cast bar iron (horseshoes that had been worn for a while and then recast, and a cock and lock plate from a percussion lock) with both pleasure and interest, as also the 3-ounce piece of platinum melted down from offcuts and waste in one of my experimental crucibles.
I then presented him with a similar crucible, which I had brought with me to England for him to use as he wished. —After taking my leave I had just enough time to pack and eat lunch before setting off for the distant station from which the 7 o’clock train to Dover was to depart. The 88 miles were covered by 10 o’clock and after such an arduous day I was glad of the chance to rest.

div.head: Dover–Gent, 5. August 1845
div.p: The Royal Mail Steamship, which owing to Queen Victoria’s forthcoming visit to Rhine-Prussia was crowded with passengers, departed from Dover at 10 o’clock in the morning and despite a fierce headwind arrived at Ostend at 3 o’clock.

I had to wait for a long time to have my case and night bag examined at customs, but only to have them opened and then immediately closed again. Some of the womenfolk who had a whole arsenal of cosmetics and finery in their cases did not fare quite so well and the douaniers were not very gallant.

After a brief lunch I went by railway via Bruges to Ghent, where I arrived at about 10 o’clock, and owing to the many foreigners in town was able to find lodgings for the night only at the third inn at which I inquired.

div.head: Gent–Köln, 6. August 1845
div.p:
August 6th. —The departure times of trains are not as exactly observed in Belgium as they are in England, where every minute counts. Instead, we passengers
had to wait nearly an hour for the officials on duty and the train finally departed at 8 o’clock instead of 7, taking us via Malines, Louvain, Liege, Aachen, Eschenyler, Düren and Kerpen to CologneDie Strecke Köln–Aachen wurde am 1. September 1841, die Verbindung Aachen–Liège am 15. Oktober 1843 eröffnet. Gent und Liège waren seit dem 1. Mai 1842 mit der Eisenbahn erschlossen., where we again arrived at 10 o’clock in the evening, and where I found very good lodgings at the Rheinischer Hof.

If there had been steam engines in use in Moses’ day, doubtless he would not have sat Joshua and Caleb in a Rhine-Prussian one and charged them “to survey the land”, since it was impossible to see anything at all from our carriage. There, where there are normally windows, these trains had curtains that because of the rain were either drawn or lowered, and while they covered the opening just enough to prevent one seeing anything outside, where they should have closed properly around the edges they did not. The wind and rain thus had free rein, giving those sitting next to them a real dowsing.

div.head: Köln–Schaffhausen, 7. bis 9. August 1845
div.p: Arriving in Cologne on August 7th, I boarded the steamer that departed at 5 o’clock for Mainz, where I arrived at 9 o’clock in the evening, departing again at 11 o’clock and arriving in Mannheim at 6 o’clock the next morning,
August 8th. I then took the 7 o’clock train via Carlsruhe to Freiburg im Breisgau, where I arrived at half past two. The post coach to Schaffhausen departed at 3 o’clock.
I arrived back home on August 9th, at half past 5 in the morning, happy and healthy, thank God, and happy to be back among my dear ones.
